title: Children of the Corn III: Urban Harvest
descriptions:
**Children of the Corn III: Urban Harvest (1995)**

"Children of the Corn III: Urban Harvest" is the third installment in the "Children of the Corn" horror franchise, which is based on the short story by Stephen King. The film, directed by Dwight H. Little, takes the rural terror of the original and transplants it to an urban setting, exploring the dark and twisted nature of a group of children who have turned to a malevolent deity for guidance and protection.

The story begins in the city of Chicago, where a group of children, led by a charismatic and ruthless boy named Isaac (played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt), have established a cult dedicated to the worship of a deity known as "He Who Walks Behind the Rows." Unlike the rural setting of the previous films, these children have taken over an abandoned warehouse in a decaying part of the city, where they carry out their rituals and maintain a reign of terror over the surrounding area.

The film's protagonist is a young woman named Sarah (played by Debi Mazar), a struggling artist who moves into a nearby apartment. Sarah is drawn into the children's world when she becomes friends with a young boy named Tad (played by Christopher Fennell), who is trying to escape the clutches of Isaac and the cult. Tad confides in Sarah about the horrors he has witnessed and the brutal punishments that await those who defy Isaac's orders.

As Sarah delves deeper into the mystery surrounding the children, she discovers that they have been responsible for a series of disappearances and murders in the neighborhood. The children, under Isaac's leadership, believe that by sacrificing adults to their deity, they will be rewarded with a utopian future where they can live without the constraints and injustices of the adult world.

Sarah's investigation puts her in direct conflict with Isaac and his followers. She teams up with a tough and resourceful police officer, Detective Harrison (played by Lawrence Monoson), who has been tracking the cult's activities. Together, they must navigate the dangerous and unpredictable world of the cult, all while trying to rescue Tad and prevent the children from carrying out their next ritual sacrifice.

The film builds tension through a series of intense and suspenseful scenes, as Sarah and Detective Harrison uncover the full extent of the cult's operations. They face numerous obstacles, including the children's superior numbers and their willingness to use violence to protect their beliefs. The climax of the film is a harrowing confrontation in the warehouse, where Sarah and Detective Harrison must fight to survive against the cult's fanatical members.

"Children of the Corn III: Urban Harvest" explores themes of innocence corrupted, the power of belief, and the dark side of human nature. It also delves into the idea of generational conflict, where the younger generation, disillusioned with the world created by adults, turns to extreme measures to create their own reality. The film is a chilling and atmospheric addition to the "Children of the Corn" series, offering a fresh take on the familiar horror elements while maintaining the core themes of the original story.
